With election day fast approaching and early voting already underway, we have received questions from our school families about several specific cuts and reductions at stake.
A Levy Q & A session for our families has been scheduled on February 25th at 6:00 PM at Falls-Lenox. This session will focus on issues specific to children ages preschool, Kindergarten, and grades 1, 2 and 3.

Please bring any questions you may have about the impact of the operating levy on your student and family including transportation concerns, impacts on teachers, class sizes, extra-curricular activities, etc., in the event of a levy failure in March.

OFCS Superintendent Dr. Jim Lloyd and Transportation Coordinator Heath Krakowiak, along with our building principals, will be there to answer your questions. (Note: Mr. Krakowiak will have maps/address lists available for those who are specifically interested in confirming whether they are inside or outside of the 2-mile busing cut-off for each building.) See you there!

STUDENTS UNITE TO HELP OTHERS WITH "YARD CHARGE"

Over the weekend, a group of students from Olmsted Falls came together to help others in our community. Olmsted Falls High School Key Club, Environmental Club, Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, and members of Olmsted Falls Middle School L.E.A.D. service organization united in a "Yard Charge" and trash pick-up.

Some students raked leaves and helped with yard clean-up, while others picked up trash in the community. Students learned about the benefits of helping others while having fun with their friends. Many thanks to those students who participated and to the adults who helped to organize the event and transport the students. Way to go, Bulldogs!

Falls-Lenox Annual Event Honors Veterans

On November 8, Falls-Lenox Primary School once again welcomed and honored veterans in our school community and beyond. Students invited the veterans in their lives to the event. Over 100 veterans attended the annual breakfast and program.

In preparation for the event, students decorated special placemats and wrote letters to veterans. Students brought in pictures of veterans to hang on the "Wall of Honor" in the school lobby. The program included patriotic songs, readings, and music, and in a moving tribute, students used sign language to communicate the words to "Taps" while Olmsted Falls High School Band members played.

We are so proud of our students and so grateful to all those who have served our country. Thank you, Veterans! For more about the special event, check out this article:

https://www.cleveland.com/community/2019/11/olmsted-falls-students-treat-veterans-with-breakfast-honor-olmsted-dates-and-data.html

post_text: The Olmsted Falls School District will be creating a Key Communicators group. The purpose of the group is to create a cross-section of leaders and influential people across the community and have an on-going conversation. The Superintendent and Treasurer would meet with this group on a quarterly basis and send out a monthly email as well. The goal is to keep these individuals up to date on central themes and happenings in the district so they can go back to their circles and share what they've learned. It is also important for them to share what they are "hearing on the street" with the district so that rising issues and rumors can be addressed in a timely fashion. This is simply another way for the district to engage with the community. There will be approximately 30 - 40 people part of this group. Go to this link to complete the form: https://forms.gle/A5oXsi1SHUf7D5Yk8

OFHS DONATES PORTION OF TROPHY ARCHIVE TO LOCAL NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION

Kudos to our OFHS Athletic Department for coordinating this week's Trophy Giveaway of past regular season tournament trophies. Thank you to those alumni and community members who came out to check out the selection and claim trophies free of charge throughout the week.

After the conclusion of the last pick-up session this afternoon, and with the help of OFMA President Jamie Reigle, OFHS was thrilled to be able to partner with Super Heroes to Kids In Ohio to donate all remaining trophies to be repurposed and distributed to children battling adversity.

OFHS Principal Dr. Holly Schafer was joined by volleyball coaches and players for the presentation of the trophy donation to Batman - our special visitor representing Super Heroes to Kids in Ohio! #CommunityPartnership

To learn more about Super Heroes to Kids in Ohio, please visit https://www.facebook.com/superheroestokidsinohio.org/

post_text: Classroom science lessons came to life this morning as a group of Falls-Lenox third graders embarked on a stream study behind the old library in Olmsted Falls! Students rotated through four different stations to research water speed, water temperature, oxygen levels and animal life. Their explorations helped them figure out if their individual hypothesis to the question "Will this stream support life?" was right or wrong. An absolutely awesome morning of engagement and learning!! Kudos to our teachers and community volunteers that made today's hands-on learning experience possible!
